summary.seg: Cambridge University Library, MS Ii.6.2 (hereafter MS Ii.6.2) is a small illuminated book of hours, produced in Flanders at the end of the fourteenth century. It follows the use of Sarum, and its calendar includes some English saints, which shows that it was always intended for the English market. It was probably imported to East Anglia which is where its earliest owners were based. The manuscript was used as an aid to personal devotion for more than two hundred years. It was used before, during, and after the English Reformation by three generations of the Roberts family of Willesden. These men, Thomas Roberts (d. 1542), his son Edmund Roberts (d. 1585), and Edmund's son Francis Roberts (d. 1632), left many traces of their ownership and reading, adding inscriptions and notes and a variety of short texts in Latin and English.

The main part of the manuscript comprises a calendar, Commemorations, Hours of the Virgin, Pentitential Psalms, and Office of the Dead. Its many blank leaves afforded space for the addition of important family records: on f. 33r is a list of the names of the six children of Thomas Roberts who were alive in 1537, along with a note that eighteen others had died: 'T Robertes hath in all xxiiij chyldern wherof xviij ben decessed'; a later hand has converted this note to the past tense. A similar list of the seven children of Edmund Roberts who were alive in 1575 is given on f. 109v. Other additions contribute notes of papal indulgences, extra prayers, charms, and a single medical recipe.

The recipe was added at the top of f. 110r by Thomas Roberts. He drew a line across the page to separate it from his next addition, a Latin prayer to St Erasmus which he signed at the bottom with his monogram. The recipe is for colic, which may have been a recurrent problem since in a remedy book that Thomas Roberts also owned, Oxford Bodleian Library, MS Rawlinson c.299, he added recipes for drinks that would soothe this complaint. The recipe 'For the Collyk' in MS Ii.6.2 takes a different approach, prescribing a plaster to be laid upon the body to relieve the condition. It specifies only five ingredients and contains very brief instructions, assuming knowledge of how the plaster would actually be prepared. Whilst confidence in the recipe's power to cure is expressed ('ye shall be holl'), an important qualification is then added: 'By the grace of God'.

Although a medical recipe may seem misplaced in a prayer book, this addendum is a reminder that the pursuit of healing frequently combined medical and devotional elements. Pre-modern society placed as much store in the power of prayer as in the therapeutic properties of substances, hence the addition in MS Ii.6.2 of a prayer 'For Women to Conceyue Childe' (f. 10r), which invokes the names of various Biblical men whose wives conceived in old age. This belief in the power of words helps to explain why recipes and charms so frequently co-exist in medieval remedy books: combinations of such materials can be seen in CUL MSS Dd.4.44, Dd.5.76, and Ll.1.18. Since popular culture perceived no hard and fast division between bodily and spiritual health, seemingly stray inscriptions of medical recipes within books of hours are therefore not as surprising as they might first appear.

Margaret Connolly
Professor of Palaeography and Codicology
University of St Andrews

msContents.textLang: Latin, with additions in Latin and Middle English

msItem.title: Notes on the changing of the moon
msItem.rubric: 1v: For the chaunge of the mone
msItem.incipit: 1v: When the prime is vpon A
msItem.explicit: 1v: then þe iiiith day before and þe xv houre

msItem.title: Verse on the life of St Mary
msItem.incipit: 1v: Anno xiiio virgo concepisti / Annis xxxiii cum nato vixisti / Et post mortem filii quem [tu peperisti] / Anno xiio assumpta fuisti.
msItem.note: Full transcription. Part of the third line lost due to damage; missing text supplied from additional copy by the same hand on f. 75r.
Added by the hand of Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Verse on meditation
msItem.incipit: 1v: Mens hominis devota / Compunctione cordis repleta / In passionis Christi constanter infixa
msItem.note: Full transcription. See also f. 1v.
Added by the hand of Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Charm against house-fire
msItem.rubric: 2r: To staunche fyre yf a house be bryni[...]
msItem.incipit: 2r: Mentem cauetam spontaneam honorem deo et patre liberacionem
msItem.note: Full transcription.
Added by Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Verse on the virtues of the Mass
msItem.incipit: 2r: The meritis of mas who can expresse
msItem.explicit: 2r: While mas is doyng lovyng the precios sacurment
msItem.note: Unique to this manuscript.
Added by an unidentified 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Indulgence
msItem.incipit: 2r: Virginis egregie faciem cum veneris ante
msItem.explicit: 2r: per quintum urbanum Episcopum tibi dico romanum
msItem.note: Added by Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.
'Episcopum' written over the erased word 'pape'.

msItem.title: Indulgence
msItem.incipit: 2r: Adde Iesus fine quociens tu dixeris Aue / bis triginta dies venie tibi Merces
msItem.note: Full transcription.
Added by Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Coat of arms of the Tilney and Thorpe families of Norfolk, impaled
msItem.note: See Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Confessional prayer
msItem.incipit: 3r: Our most mercyfull fader lord god knowyng our frelite and redynes to all synners
msItem.explicit: 3r: hartis and the soner turn theym to goodenes and grace . Amen
msItem.note: Added by Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Short text on protection against miscarriage
msItem.incipit: 3v: In quacumque domo nomen fuerit vel imago / virginis eximie dorothee matiris alme / Nullus abortyphus infans nascetur in illa / Nec quisquam poterit in ibi mala morte periere
msItem.note: Full transcription.
The text is prose but presented as verse. It describes the benefits of keeping an image of St Dorothy in the home as a protection against miscarriage.

msItem.title: Prayer to St Dorothy
msItem.incipit: 3v: Virgo pia dorothea pollens miraculis
msItem.explicit: 3v:Qui carnem diabolum mundum que vicisti
msItem.note: Added by an unidentified 15th-century hand, probably the same as that responsible for the following two items.

msItem.title: Prayer to St Dorothy
msItem.incipit: 3v: Ora pro \nobis/ beata dorothea / Vt digni efficiamus promissionibus Christi
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by an unidentified 15th-century hand, probably the same as that responsible for the preceding and following item.

msItem.title: Prayer to St Dorothy
msItem.incipit: 3v: In cuius nomine gloriosa virgo et marter dorothea multorum genera
msItem.explicit: 3v: gaudere valeamus in celis per Christum dominum nostrum Amen
msItem.note: Added by an unidentified 15th-century hand, probably the same as that responsible for the preceding two items.

msItem.title: Anti-clerical verse against Pope Alexander VI
msItem.incipit: 3v: Vendit Alexander / Crucis altaria Cristum / Emerat ipse prius / Vendere iure postest
msItem.note: Added by an unidentified late 15th-/early 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Prayer to St Clement
msItem.incipit: 10r: Dedisti domine habitaculum Martiri tuo Clementi in mari
msItem.explicit: 10r: Et constituisti super opera manuum tuarum.
msItem.note: Added by Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Prayer to St Clement
msItem.incipit: 10r: Deus qui nos anima beati Clementis Martiris tui atque pontificis
msItem.explicit: 10r: quoque passionis imitemur per Christum dominum nostrum amen
msItem.note: Added by Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Prayer in aid of conception
msItem.textLang: Latin, with rubric in Middle English
msItem.rubric: 10r: Prayer for women to conceyve childe
msItem.incipit: 10r: Dominus noster Ihesus Christus qui de beata virgine Marie pro humani generis
msItem.explicit: 10r: concedat qui cum deo patre et spirito sancto viuit et regnat deus per omnia secula seculorum Amen
msItem.note: Added by Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.
Prayer invokes the names of Biblical couples whose wives conceived in old age, with similar wording to that found in charms.

msItem.title: Suffrage to the Holy Trinity
msItem.incipit: 11r: Domine deus omnipotens pater et filius et spiritus sanctus da mihi famulo tuo uictoriam contra omnes inimicos
msItem.note: Annotated by Thomas Roberts (1470-1542) and possibly Edmund Roberts (1520-1585); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Suffrage to the Holy Face
msItem.note: Antiphons (RH 18189, 23474), the Kyrieleison, and prayer 'Deus qui nobis signati lumine'.

msItem.title: Prayer to Christ attributed to Joseph of Arimathea
msItem.textLang: Latin, with rubric in Middle English
msItem.rubric: 14r: The prayer of Joseph of Armathy ar Crist Passion
msItem.incipit: 14r: Adoramus te Christe Ihesu et benedicimus tibi quia
msItem.explicit: 14r: + adoramus te etcetera + pater noster aue + Credo in deum et cetera
msItem.note: Added by Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Opening lines of Psalms 123, 54, 67, 150 and 121
msItem.note: Added by Edmund Roberts (1520-1585); see Provenance for further details.

These Psalms each occur in the Prayer to Christ copied above by Thomas Roberts. Concludes with 'Qui crucis in patibulo / adoramus te Christi Ihesu pater aue et credo', also repeating a component of the prayer above.

msItem.title: Suffrage to St Michael
msItem.note: Antiphon (RH 6908) and prayer 'Deus qui montem garganium'.

msItem.title: Prayer to St Cornelius
msItem.rubric: 15v: T sancto Cornelio papa et christi martire
msItem.incipit: 15v: O Corneli martir Christi papa sanctus qui fuisti hic in terris
msItem.explicit: 15v: ora pro nobis sancte Corneli Martir Christi vt digni efficiamur promissionibus Christi
msItem.note: Added by Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.
'Papa' erased and 'episcopo' written above, in both the rubric and opening line, probably by Edmund Roberts (1520-1585) or perhaps by Michael Roberts (1519-1544). See Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Prayer to St Cornelius
msItem.incipit: 16r: Deus qui conspicis quia ex nulla nostra virtute subsistimus
msItem.explicit: 16r: atque pontificis Cornelii intercessione placatus auerte per Christum dominum nostrum amen
msItem.note: Added by Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Suffrage to St Christopher
msItem.note: Antiphon (RH 39618) and prayer 'Concede quaesumus omnipotens et misericors deus ut qui beati christofori'.

msItem.title: Prayer to St John the Baptist
msItem.incipit: 17v: Gaude Iohannes Baptista qui inuentris clausus cista
msItem.explicit: 17v: Tu nos a sceleribus solue Ihesu criste precursoris precibus Iohannis Baptiste

msItem.title: Prayer to St John the Baptist
msItem.incipit: 17v: Beate Iohannes Baptista Christi precursor atque preco
msItem.explicit: 17v: et ad lucem celestis gaudii perducat pro Christum dominum nostrum amen

msItem.title: Prayer to St John the Baptist
msItem.incipit: 18r: Sancte Iohannes Baptista electe dei tu es angelus dei qui venisti ante faciem domini
msItem.explicit: 18r: vt mereamur vitam possidere etername amen
msItem.note: Added by Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Prayer to St John the Baptist
msItem.incipit: 18r: Sancte Iohannes Baptista qui meruistu saluatorem mundi
msItem.explicit: 18r: appropinquare promisit cui est honor et gloria per infinita seculorum secula amen
msItem.note: Added by Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Suffrage to St John the Baptist
msItem.note: Antiphon (RH 26987) and prayer 'Beate iohannes baptista christi precursor'.

msItem.title: Suffrage to St John the Evangelist
msItem.note: Antiphon (RH 27075) and prayer 'Ecclesiam tuam quesumus domine'.

msItem.title: Prayer to St George
msItem.incipit: 22r: George deo care saluatorem deprecare vt gubernat angliam
msItem.explicit: 22r: visibilies et invisibiles sint contra nos valde debiles
msItem.note: Added by Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Prayer to St George
msItem.incipit: 22r: Deus qui nos beati Georgii martirus tui meritus et intercessione letificas concede propitius vt qui eius benificia possumus dono tue gratie consequamur per dominum nostrum Ihesum Christum et cetera
msItem.note: Full transcription.
Added by an unidentified hand of the 16th century, perhaps Edmund Roberts (1520-1585) or Michael Roberts (1519-1544); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Suffrage to St George
msItem.note: Antiphon (RH 7242) and prayer 'Omnipotens sempiterne deus'.

msItem.title: Prayer to St Peter
msItem.incipit: 23v: Ianitor celi qui accepisti claues regni celorum precor te pastor boni intercede pro me amen
msItem.note: Full transcription.
Added by an unidentified hand of the 15th-century, the same as that responsible for the following item.

msItem.title: Prayer to St Mary
msItem.incipit: 23v: Aue et gaude mater domini nostri Ihesum Christi regina celi
msItem.explicit: 23v: sanctificamen voluntatem ad implere amen
msItem.note: Added by an unidentified hand of the 15th-century, the same as that responsible for the preceding item.

msItem.title: Prayer to Jesus
msItem.incipit: 23v: O my seuereyn lord Iesu þe very sone off allmyty god and of þe most clene and gloryous virgine seynt mary
msItem.explicit: 24r: as þy seruant lord all myghty god Iesu I synfull creature aske þe mercy amen
msItem.note: Added by an unidentified hand of the 15th century.

msItem.title: Prayer to the Holy Cross
msItem.incipit: 24r: Per crucis hoc signum fugiat procul omni malignum et per idem signum saluetur quodque benignum per signum sancte crucis de inimicis nostris liberet nos deus noster amen
msItem.note: Full transcription.
Added by an unidentified hand of the 15th century, the same as that responsible for the following item.

msItem.title: Prayer to St Erasmus
msItem.incipit: 24r: Praesta quaesumus omnipotens deus vt qui beati hersaimi matiris tui
msItem.explicit: 24r: et vnum credo et dicatur in qualibus die dominica
msItem.note: Added by an unidentified hand of the 15th century, the same as that responsible for the preceding item.

msItem.title: Suffrage to St Catherine
msItem.note: Antiphon (RH 6991) and prayer 'Deus qui beatam Katherinam uirginem et martyrem'.

msItem.title: Prayer to St Dorothy
msItem.incipit: 25v: Inuicitissima Christi martir et virgo sancta dorothea martiris seceleribus dulcim sponsum tuum
msItem.explicit: 25v: postulare ora pro nobis sancta dorothea vt dignum
msItem.note: Added by Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Prayer to St Dorothy
msItem.incipit: 25v: Omnipotens sempiterne deus in cuius nomine gloriosa virgo et martir dorothea multorum tormentorum
msItem.explicit: 25v: celerem senciamus per Christum dominum nostrum amen
msItem.note: Added by Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Prayer at the Levation
msItem.rubric: 25v: sey this prayer at the leuacioun / at þe laueacioun
msItem.incipit: 25v: Te veneranda caro Christi venerantur adoro corpus
msItem.explicit: 25v: per te mundetur meus sensus purificetur
msItem.note: Added by Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Prayer to St Frideswide
msItem.incipit: 26r: De regali stupe nata Frideswida nobilis
msItem.explicit: 26r: ora pro nobis beata Frideswida vt dignum efficur promissus Christi oremus
msItem.note: Added by Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Prayer to St Frideswide
msItem.incipit: 26r: Deus qui beate Frideswide virgini teu felicitatem terrenam
msItem.explicit: 26r: consequi valeamus per Christum dominum nostrum amen
msItem.note: Added by Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Suffrage to St Margaret
msItem.note: Antiphon (RH 7011) and prayer 'Deprecationem nostram quesumus domine benignus'.

msItem.title: Prayer for daily use
msItem.rubric: 27v: Oracio cotidiana pro beneficiis dei et vocetur deo gracias
msItem.incipit: 27v: Omnipotens sempiterne deu te adoro te glorifico tibi gracias ago
msItem.explicit: 27v: diligere laudare adorare glorificare et gracias agere hic et imperpetuum amen
msItem.note: Added by Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Suffrage to St Mary Magdalene
msItem.note: Antiphon (RH 6895) and prayer 'Deus qui beatam mariam magdalenam penitentiam ita tibi placitam'.

msItem.title: Prayer to St Mary
msItem.author: Richard Fitzjames (attributed)
msItem.rubric: 31v: Oracio ad beatam Mariam compositam per Ricardum Fitz James londoniensis episcopum
msItem.incipit: 31v: Euge dicta sanctis oraculis antequam nata visu prophetico
msItem.explicit: 31v: et honor tibi cum sovole mundi futuri per cuncta secula amen
msItem.note: Attributed in the rubric to Richard Fitzjames (d. 1522), bishop of London.
Added by Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: The dates of birth of Thomas Roberts's children
msItem.rubric: 33r: The tyme of byrth of Thomas Robertz children
msItem.finalRubric: 33r: Thise childern were lyvyng Ao xxix h viii mense iunii . T Robertz hath in all xxiiii chyldern wherof xviii ben decessed
msItem.note: Added by Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

Six entries, noting the births of Dorothy, Anne, Alice, Michael, Edmund and John, with closing rubric dated June 1537. For further discussion of the compilation of the entries, as well as the erasures, see Connolly (2019), p. 168.

msItem.title: Prayer to St Mary / Indulgence
msItem.incipit: 55r: Aue virgo graciosa stella sole clarior
msItem.explicit: 55r: Ihesus Cristus te coronat in celis sublimior alleluia
msItem.finalRubric: 55r: Pater noster aue maria ab alexanda papa sixtus concedare plena
msItem.note: Attributed in the final line to Pope Alexander VI (reg. 1492-1503), 'implying an indulgence of some kind' (Connolly (2019), p. 212).

msItem.title: Prayer to St Botulph
msItem.incipit: 58v: O lilium odiferum spergeus ubique viuificum suauitatis
msItem.explicit: 58v: Scola glorie uiduit eum
msItem.note: Prayer added by an unidentified hand of the 15th century, the same as that reponsible for the following item.
Rubric written in the margin by Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Prayer to St Botulph
msItem.incipit: 58v: Deus qui es uera felicitas et requies beatorum beati botulphi
msItem.explicit: 58v: meritis perticipemus et premiis . Per Christum .
msItem.note: Prayer added by an unidentified hand of the 15th century, the same as that reponsible for the preceding item.
Initial D written into space left for decorative initial by Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Hymns and prayers to the Virgin
msItem.note: Hymn (RH 18310?); prayers 'Deus qui de beate marie virginis', 'O intemerata', and 'Obsecro te'; seven prayers in honour of the Virgin, with an indulgence for remission of a hundred days in the name of Pope Clement (RH 21899); final prayer 'Te deprecor sanctissima maria'.

msItem.title: Hymns on the Passion of Christ
msItem.author: Johannes Lemovicensis
msItem.note: Ten hymns excerpted from Johannes Lemovicensis / John of Limoges, De passione Christi. The first eight are addressed to the Crucifix, Cross, Head and Five Wounds of Christ, the last two to the Virgin and St John the Evangelist: RH 14081; 20594; 23377; 33260; 'Ave tu sinistra' (not in RH); 39355; 'Salve vulnus dextri pedis'; 'Levi pedis perforati' (not in RH), 30648; 28714.

msItem.title: Prayer
msItem.note: 'Omnipotens sempiterne deus qui unigenitum filium tuum'.

msItem.title: De septem verbis Christi
msItem.author: Bede
msItem.rubric: 70v: Oratio venerabilis bede presbiteri de septem verbis christi in cruce pendentis
msItem.incipit: 70v: Domine ihesu christe qui septem verba die ultimo vite tue in cruce pendens dixisti

msItem.title: Prayers to Christ, the body of Christ and indulgences
Meditation
msItem.incipit: 73v: Valde salutaris ; nec interdum nec noctu mente vnguam deponenda
msItem.note: Three groups of three phrases, bracketed under the titles 'Preterita', 'Presentia' and 'Futura'.
Added by Edmund Roberts (1520-1585), who also added his initials and the date 1585; see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Verse on the life of St Mary
msItem.incipit: 75r: Anno quartodecimo virgo concepisti / Annis triginta tribus cum nato vixisti / Et post mortem filii quem tu peperisti / Anno duodecimo assumpta fuisti
msItem.note: Full transcription. See also f. 1v.
Added by the hand of Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Verse on the Passion
msItem.incipit: 75r: O homo si vis letare mecum / Passio mea sit semper tecum
msItem.note: Full transcription.
Added by the hand of Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Meditation
msItem.incipit: 75r: Est mens hominis deuota / Compunccionem cordi repleta / In passione Christi constanter infixa
msItem.note: Full transcription. See also f. 1v.
Added by the hand of Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Note on the foundation of St Mary's shrine at Walsingham
msItem.incipit: 75r: Anno domini millesimo sexagesimo primo capella beate Marie de Walsyngham in comitatis Norff' fuit fundata et incepta
msItem.note: Full transcription.
Added by the hand of Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Prayer to St Mary about St Anne
msItem.textLang: Latin, with final rubric in Middle English
msItem.incipit: 102r: Et benedicta sit sanctissima mater tua Anna ex qua sine macula tua caro processit virginea amen.
msItem.finalRubric: 102r: Pardon vi ml dayes and iiiixx
msItem.note: The final rubric suggests that the prayer functioned as an indulgence.

msItem.title: Prayer to St Etheldreda
msItem.incipit: 102r: Aue gemina preciosa uirgo decens et formosa etheldreda deo digna
msItem.explicit: 102r: Intercede pro nobis ad deum qui te eligit
msItem.note: Added by an unidentified hand of the 15th century, the same as that responsible for the following item.

msItem.title: Prayer to St Etheldreda
msItem.incipit: 102r: Deus qui eximie cascitatis preuilegio sanctissimam uirginem tuam etheldredam
msItem.explicit: 102r: memoria apud te semper habeatur in celis . Per Christum dominum nostrum .
msItem.note: Added by an unidentified hand of the 15th century, the same as that reponsible for the preceding item.

msItem.title: Prayer
msItem.incipit: 102v: Da nobis domine quamuis pie supplicacionis
msItem.explicit: 102v: et te miserante cessare per dominum nostrum amen

msItem.title: Levation prayer
msItem.incipit: 102v: O Ihesu lord welcom thu be
msItem.explicit: 103r: lese the blys that thou art in
msItem.note: Added by an unidentified hand of the 15th or 16th century. See also f. 103v.

msItem.title: Prayer on the Sacrament
msItem.incipit: 103r: Anima Ihesu Christi sanctifica me corpus
msItem.explicit: 103r: vt cum angelis tuis laudem te in secula seculorum amen
msItem.finalRubric: 103r: At þe leuacion tyme say stella celi extirpauit

msItem.title: Prayer
msItem.incipit: 103r: Adesto domine supplicacionibus nostris et viam famulorum tuorum
msItem.explicit: 103r: protegamur auxilio per dominum nostrum Ihesum Christum filium tuum et cetera
msItem.note: According to Connolly (2019), p. 214, copied by the same hand as the following item.

msItem.title: Prayer to a guardian angel
msItem.incipit: 103r: Angele qui meus es custos pietate superna / Me tibi commissum salua defende guverna
msItem.explicit: 103r: protegamur auxilio per dominum nostrum Ihesum Christum filium tuum et cetera
msItem.note: According to Connolly (2019), p. 214, copied by the same hand as the preceding item.

msItem.title: Note on a date of birth
msItem.incipit: 103v: Memorandum that Anne Barnesdale was borne 16 day of September 1588 on a Monday
msItem.note: Full transcription.
Added by an unidentified hand of the late 16th century.

msItem.title: Levation prayer
msItem.incipit: 102v: O Ihesu lord wellcum thu be
msItem.explicit: 103r: lese the blysse that thu art in
msItem.note: Added by an unidentified hand of the 15th or 16th century. See also f. 103v.

msItem.title: Erased text
msItem.note: ?Seven lines of erased text immediately beneath the levation prayer.

msItem.title: Charm against fever
msItem.rubric: 108r: Oracio bona pro febribus pater noster aue maria
msItem.incipit: 108r: Theobal quith et quth kanai per veritatem
msItem.explicit: 108r: Tetragramaton . In nomine patris et filii et spiritus sancti amen
msItem.note: Added by the hand of Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Anecdote about St Peter
msItem.incipit: 108r: Sanctus petrus iacebat super marinoriam petram
msItem.explicit: 108v: Impare me amen . In nomine patris et filii et spiritus sancti amen
msItem.note: Added by the hand of Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.
Perhaps a continuation of the previous item, since mention is also made here of fevers.

msItem.title: Instructions for praying and almsgiving, with a prayer
msItem.incipit: 108v: ye shall say a Ml tymes aue maria and ye shall sey theym in x dayes
msItem.explicit: 109r: ye shall sure haue that thyng ye pray for laufully with goddis grace
msItem.finalRubric: 109r: I youse thys prayer well every daye Edmond Roberts inquit
msItem.note: Final rubric added by Edmund Roberts (1520-1585).

msItem.title: Note on the death of Edmund Roberts
msItem.incipit: 109r: Anno Domini 1585 . the first daye of Juene departed owght off this lyffe Edmond Roberts...
msItem.note: Added by an unidentified hand of the late 16th century, perhaps Francis Roberts (1551-1631) or another of Edmund's children.

msItem.title: Moral verse
msItem.author: Edmund Roberts
msItem.incipit: 109v: Ioye in god whoes whoes [sic] grace is beste
msItem.explicit: 109v: More nere ys deathe then thowe censt espye

msItem.title: The dates of birth of Edmund Roberts's children
msItem.note: Added by Edmund Roberts (1520-1585); see Provenance for further details.
Seven entries, noting the births of Francis, Katherine, Mary, Elizabeth, Thomas, Edmond and Mary, with the date 1575. For further discussion, see Connolly (2019), p. 217.

msItem.title: Recipe for colic
msItem.incipit: 110r: Take wurminhode comyn sauge bred and veneger and make a playstre and ley it to your laske and ye xalbe holl by þe grace of god
msItem.note: Added by an unidentified hand of the 15th century.

msItem.title: Prayer to St Erasmus
msItem.incipit: 110r: Herasme flos decoris honestatis pro amore Ihesu Christi magnum open reliquisti
msItem.explicit: 110r: et regnas deus per omnia secular seculorum amen
msItem.note: Added by the hand of Thomas Roberts (1470-1542); see Provenance for further details.

foliation.p: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the recto side of each leaf, by H.L. PinkPink, H. L.. Folio numbers 20-21, 29-30, 32, 74 and 104-107 assigned to leaves determined on the basis of collation to be missing from the volume (as per historic foliation practice at Cambridge University Library). (See Collation for further details on this point).

collation.p: At their core, most of the quires of this manuscript comprise eight leaves, however their structure is obscured by the addition in numerous places of single leaves bearing full-page miniatures. The picture is especially confused after the calendar, where there are several short suffrage texts interspersed with miniatures of the saints to which these prayers are directed. In an unpublished description of the manuscript, M.R. James described these simply as 'loose leaves'. Numerous of them have been repaired along the spinefold and it is possible that leaves that were originally singletons have been joined together to form artificial bifolia, since these may be more securely sewn into the binding; unfortunately, the tightness of the binding precludes a deeper examination of their structure. The leaf signatures in this section (written in red-orange ink, now much-faded) cannot necessarily be taken as an accurate guide to the quires' structure: although medieval, they are later additions.

The collation of the manuscript by H.L. Pink, perhaps around the time the manuscript was rebound in 1960, and his addition of leaf signatures to indicate the sequence of leaves in each quire, only adds to the confusion. Pink often took the stubs of these decorative leaves - which had only ever been singletons - as evidence of a leaf having been cancelled in that location: hence the frequent occurrence in his formula (written on the rear pastedown) of quires of ten leaves, a structure atypical for manuscripts of this kind and of this date and place of origin.

In this situation, it seems unwise to superimpose yet another interpretation of the structure of the suffrage / miniature quires (Quires 2-4 in Pink's formula) and risk further compounding the confusion. Instead, they are noted below as being of uncertain structure. In order to minimise the disjuncture between this formula and that which preceded it, but yet permit corrections to be made, the numbering of the quires that follow the suffrages and miniatures will include the letters assigned by H.L. Pink. What is provided here broadly follows the collation as given by M.R. James in an unpublished description (see Source for further details).
3 medieval parchment endleaves
Quire 1/a6 (ff. 4-9)
Quires Two-Four/b-d??uncertain (ff. 10-31)
Quire 5/e8+2 (ff. 33-42: ff. 33 and 37 are single leaves inserted before the 1st and after the 3rd leaves of the quire)
Quire 6/f8+6 (ff. 43-56: ff. 44, 47, 49, 51, 53 and 55 are single leaves inserted after the 1st, 3rd, 4th, 5th, 6th and 7th leaves of the quire)
Quire 7/g8+1 (ff. 57-65: f. 59 is a single leaf inserted after the 2nd leaf of the quire)
Quire 8/h8+1-1 (ff. 66-73: f. 68 is a single leaf inserted after the 2nd leaf of the quire; the final leaf of the quire is missing, but may have originally been blank)
Quire 9/i8+1 (ff. 75-83: f. 75 is a single leaf inserted before the 1st leaf of the quire)
Quire 10/k8+1 (ff. 84-92: f. 84 is a single leaf inserted before the 1st leaf of the quire)
Quire 11/l8 (ff. 93-100)
Quire 12/mthree/8-5 (ff. 101-103: three leaves, but probably originally a quire of 8, of which the 4th-8th are now missing, but may have originally been blank)

signatures.p: Leaf signatures, medieval but added after the insertion of the single leaves that bear miniatures.

condition.p: Several of the miniatures have been rubbed and the pigments smudged (ff. 10v, 26v, 30v, 33v, 44v, 51v).
Pigments have also flaked away in places (10v, 59v) and transferred to facing leaves (44v-45r).
Numerous leaves have been heavily thumbed at the edges (e.g. 31r-31v, 39r-43v).

layout.seg: Text: frame and line ruling in red ink, single column, 24 lines to the page, written below top line.
Calendar: frame and line ruling in red ink, single column, 36 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Text and calendar written in textura quadrata.

decoNote.p:
Twenty-one (originally twenty-two) full-page miniatures, each on single leaves and probably prepared by an artist as a standard set:
10v: Throne of Mercy ('Domine deus omnipotens')
12v: Vernicle ('Salve sancta facies')
14v: St Michael and dragon ('Gaude princeps superiorum')
16v: St Christopher ('O sancta Cristofore')
18v: St John the Evangelist (left) and St John the Baptist (right) ('Gaude Iohannes Baptista'; 'Beate Iohannes Baptista'; 'Gaude pater via morum')
22v: St George and dragon ('Georgi martyr')
24v: St Catherine ('Gaude virgo Katherina')
26v: St Margaret ('Gaude virgo Margareta')
28v: St Anne with Virgin and Child (memoria removed)
[30v: ?St Mary Magdalene; miniature removed ('Gaude pia magdalena')]
33v: Annunciation ('Matins of Virgin')
37v: Visitation (Lauds)
44v: Nativity (Prime)
47v: Annunciation to the Shepherds (Terce)
49v: Adoration of the Magi (Sext)
51v: Massacre of the Innocents (None)
53v: Flight into Egypt (Vespers)
55v: Presentation in the Temple (Compline)
59v: Our Lady of Humility ('Salve virgo virginum')
68v: Crucifixion ('Omnibus consideratis paradisus voluptatis')
75v: Man of Sorrows with Instruments of the Passion ('Penitential Psalms')
84v: Funeral service ('Office of the Dead')

Ten five-line initials, in blue or orange with internal white filigree and enclosing scrollwork of blue and orange flowers, on gold background; with gold, blue and mauve single bar borders descending from the initial, sprouting branches tipped with blue, orange and gold flowers, ivy and trefoil leaves, at the Hours of the Virgin (ff. 34r, 38r, 45r, 50r, 52r, 54r, 56r), the Penitential Psalms (f. 76r), the Office of the Dead (f. 85r) and the Commendatio animarum (f. 95v).
Two- and three-line initials in gold, on blue and mauve background, at the opening of the months in the Calendar, and of prayers and verses.
One-line initials in gold or blue with purple or red pen flourishing.
Miniatures framed by blue and mauve panels with white patterns, gold ornamentation, and short black sprays terminating in gold ivy leaves, and surmounted by turreted arches, simulating stone masonry.
Gold, blue and mauve bbars extending from illuminated initials into branches tipped with blue, orange and gold flowers, ivy and trefoil leaves.
Impaled coats of arms of the Tilney and Thorpe families of Norfolk (f. 2v).

note.p: Feast day of St Etheldreda (17 October) inserted in the Calendar (f. 8v; see also prayer added to f. 102v).

Numerous additions by various identified and unidentified hands of the 15th and 16th centuries, comprising prayers, charms, family records and other matter. These have been catalogued as part of the contents of the manuscript. See Contents and Provenance for further details.

binding.p: Full goatskin (W.H. Smith and Son, Ltd W.H. Smith & Son, London, 1960).
Spine labels from a former (probably 18th-century) binding have been adhered to the front pastedown.

origin.p: 'One of the earliest Flemish Hours produced for English patrons [...]. Despite stylistic similarities with Northern Netherlandish manuscripts, [a] Bruges origin is supported by [a] group of manuscripts of s. xiv/xv illuminated in [the] same style in [the] circle of [the] Master of Pink Baldachins, some of which contain Bruges calendars (e.g. Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS. Canon. liturg. 125)'.

provenance.p: Addition of St Etheldreda, patron saint of Ely, to the Calendar (f. 8v) and of a prayer to her (f. 102v) point to early ownership in East Anglia.

Addition of obituaries to the calendar indicate that the manuscript was in Suffolk by the first half of the fifteenth century:
f. 5r: 'Obitus domine Margerie Carbonell uxoris domini I[ohannis] C[arbonell] m[ilitis], Anno domini Millesimo CCCCmo vicesimo vito, littera dominicalis e' / 'The death of Margerie Carbonell Carbonell, Margerie , wife of Sir John Carbonell Carbonell, Sir John [of Badingham in Hoxne Hundred], in the year of Our Lord 1426, dominical letter e': i.e. 2 March 1426 (not 4 March, the line on which the inscription begins).
f. 8r: 'Obitus Margarete Heuenyngham, Anno domini Millesimo CCCCxxxii, littera dominicalis G' / 'The death of Margaret Heveningham Heveningham, Margaret , in the year of Our Lord 1432, dominical letter G': i.e. 2 September 1432 (not 1 September, the line on which the inscription begins).

The individuals named may have been former owners, though no explicit evidence of their possession of the manuscript exists, and it is equally possible that the book was in the hands of unnamed relatives.

Addition of impaled coat of arms of the Tilney and Thorpe familiesTilney and Thorpe families (f. 2v) indicates that the manuscript was later in Norfolk, later in the 15th and/or in the early 16th centuries.

Additions and notes relating to members of the Roberts family indicate the manuscript was in Middlesex, certainly during the second half of the 16th century and perhaps for longer:
f. 33r: 'The tyme of Byrth of Thomas Robertz Children', with dates of birth ranging from 1508 to 1531.
f. 109v: further dates of birth for Roberts family children, with dates ranging from 1550 to 1574.

The individuals named may have possessed or accessed the manuscript, individually or jointly, and at varying times, however the only evidence that points more firmly towards ownership are the recurrent additions and inscriptions by Thomas Roberts (1470-1542)Roberts, Thomas, 1470-1542 and Edmund Roberts (1521-1585)Roberts, Edmund, 1520-1585 of Willesden. The latter wrote his name in many places, usually across openings that contain miniatures, and often with the date 1553, which may be when he acquired the book (ff. 4r, 33v-34r, 37v-38r, 44v-45r, 54r, etc).

f. 103v: a further inscription relating to a child's date of birth, probably made by a parent or other family member and perhaps after the manuscript had left the possession of the Roberts family: 'Memorandum that Anne Barnesdale was borne 16 day of September 1588 on a Monday'.
John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : no. 151 (f. 2r) in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697).

history.acquisition: Presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 : donation bookplate engraved by John Pine Pine, John, 1690-1756 in 1736 on front pastedown.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on the description provided by Paul Binski and Patrick Zutshi, with the collaboration of Stella Panayotova, Western Illuminated Manuscripts: A Catalogue of the Collection in Cambridge University Library (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2011) (used here by kind permission of Cambridge University Press) and an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1926 and 1930 by M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74). It is also indebted for the identification of the hands responsible for the various additions to Margaret Connolly, Sixteenth-century readers, fifteenth-century books: continuities of reading in the English reformation (2019).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.
